context: Huguenot immigrants did not disperse or settle in different parts of the country, but rather, formed three societies or congregations; one in the city of New York, another <b5_0><b6_0><b7_0>21 miles<b7_0/><b6_0/><b5_0/> north of <b9_0>New York<b9_0/> in a town which they named <a0_0><a0_1><a0_2>New Rochelle<a0_2/><a0_1/><a0_0/>, and a third further upstate in <a1_0><a1_1><a1_2><b8_0>New Paltz<b8_0/><a1_2/><a1_1/><a1_0/>. <a2_2>The <a2_0>"<a2_1>Huguenot Street Historic District<a2_1/>" in New Paltz<a2_2/><a2_0/> has been designated a National Historic Landmark site and contains <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2>the oldest street in the United States of America<a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/>. A small group of Huguenots also settled on the south shore of <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2>Staten Island<a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/> along the New York Harbor, for which the current neighborhood of Huguenot was named.
